;有关抗洪救灾资金被挪用的报道在中国引发愤怒和恐惧本月毁灭性洪水过后，同样的事情可能会再次发生。

;

;上个月末，河南省政府的一份审计报告记录了为 2021 年夏季拨出约 100 亿元人民币（14 亿美元）的重建资金河南的洪水被地方官员滥用或挪作他用。

;

;上周末，官方媒体《光明日报》发表了对该问题的评论，尽管救援工作仍在进行中，但这个故事开始在网上迅速传播。上周，北京及河北、吉林、黑龙江等省遭遇特大洪涝灾害，已造成30多人死亡，首都录得140年来最大降雨量。

;

;截至目前，中央已向重灾区下拨救灾资金5.2亿元。

;

;2021年河南夏季特大洪涝灾害，造成近400人死亡，造成近400人死亡。由于死亡人数过多和地方官员应急响应不力，全国范围内一片哗然。

;

;“烛光晚餐”：中国洪灾区餐厅招待200名救灾人员

;

;据发布的报告2022年1月，国务院调查组通报，中部地区遭遇“历史罕见强降雨”，受灾群众近1500万人，经济损失超1200亿元。

;

;河南省尚未公布了重建费用，但媒体报道称这一数字至少达到 200 亿元。

;

;2021 年 11 月，当局在官方《郑州日报》上发表文章，承诺“认真执行严格财务纪律，加强资金管理，督促各市县尽快将资金直达基层和受灾群众，确保宝贵的救灾重建资金用得妥当。

;

;但是审计报告揭露了一系列问题。其中，9个县和1个省属企业共划拨4.05亿元，但未按规定使用。

;

;另有2个县被发现挪用资金。超过3000万元的重建资金。

;

;“建设资金是国家专门下发的，为什么没有用在老百姓身上？谁这么大胆？有什么规定吗？”光明日报评论称。

;

;“一定要明确这笔钱是国家的、人民的，钱的用途必须查清。”

;

;该报告在社交媒体平台微博上被屏蔽，但有关该问题的帖子被广泛分享，一些帖子吸引了数千条评论。

;

;全球变暖导致更长时间、更极端的天气事件：气候科学家

;

;该平台上的一条热门评论简单地说：“2021年河北很快就会变成郑州。”

;

;对媒体机构凤凰网的一篇被分享或评论的帖子获得最多点赞的回复之一超过 15,000 次阅读：“此时此刻发生了多么令人尴尬的新闻。”

;

;另一条回复说：“我们现在不要因为这个而捐款[救灾]。”

;中国正在采取严格措施确保大学毕业生就业数据的真实性，据报道，在就业市场充满挑战的情况下，大学面临着捏造就业率的压力，这对中国本已陷入困境的经济构成了最重大的威胁。

;

;教育部已向全国派遣特别检查组，调查就业情况- 周五，随着媒体报道披露，大学通过强迫毕业生伪造就业记录或谎报就业状况来操纵就业率，该机构表示，为了数据准确性并打击任何造假行为。

;

;教育部重申，全国高校不得“以任何方式强迫毕业生签订就业协议、劳动合同，不得将学位证书、文凭的颁发与毕业生合同挂钩”。

;

;作为青年失业问题飙升，中国“白纸”毕业生被视为失业

;

;教育部和其他省级部门也在收集不良行为举报，对捏造数据的人将进行处罚，同时跟踪调查以调查就业情况据教育部称，2023年大学毕业生的就业率将被实施。

;

;“我认为中国青年失业的实际状况可能比数据显示的更糟糕，因为大学有动机抬高就业率， ”新加坡管理大学法学教授高亨利说道。 “有报道称，大学向自己的毕业生提供就业机会只是为了掩盖数据。”

;

;大学就业率与资金、助学金、新生录取情况甚至专业是否会被录取密切相关。取消——教育部规定就业率连续两年低于60%的专业可取消。

;

;16-24岁年龄段失业率再创新高6 月份为 21.3%，高于 5 月份的 20.8%，预计 7 月和 8 月将进一步上升，今年有 1158 万名大学毕业生离开校园，创历史新高。

;

;分析师表示，中国正处于最困难的时期20世纪70年代以来的青年就业时代，短期内经济复苏仍举步维艰，占城镇就业80%以上的私营部门仍难以重拾信心和动力，挑战不会在短期内消失。

;

;“高校要严守就业数据真实准确的底线，严格审核每位毕业生的就业材料，重点核实‘灵活就业’相关数据。”教育部表示。

;

;“更多自由”：中国年轻人在惨淡的就业市场中拥抱“灵活”工作

;

;据官方通讯社新华社主办的双月刊《中国评论》报道，学校告诉学生将零工或“灵活就业”作为就业状况，有的学校甚至编造数据，让就业率看起来比实际更讨人喜欢。

;

;一些企业甚至提供有偿“盖章”服务来帮助据《北京青年报》报道，毕业生持有虚假就业文件。

;

;中国共青团在最近的一份报告中指出，伪造就业率可能会导致“深远后果”。

;

;报告称，“无论就业市场多么困难，我们都不能淡化真相”，并补充说，有必要重新校准思想偏差，并改革大学生就业状况的评估体系。< /p>; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 21:20:02 +0800 South Korean park releases photos of 1-month-old twin panda cubshttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3230299/south-korean-park-releases-photos-1-month-old-twin-panda-cubs?utm_source=rss_feed

;上个月出生的双胞胎大熊猫在韩国最大的主题公园庆祝一个月生日公园、爱宝乐园熊猫世界。

;

;该组织周一公布了周六拍摄的照片，即照片满 30 天的前一天。这对备受赞誉的双胞胎明显更丰满，皮毛更多，眼睛、耳朵、肩膀、手臂和腿周围都有独特的黑色斑纹。

;

;这对雌性双胞胎于 7 月 7 日在公园出生，妈妈艾宝，爸爸乐宝。它们的重量分别为180克和140克。艾宝和她的两只幼崽都很健康。

;

;在为期30天的健康检查中，双胞胎大熊猫的体重分别为1.1公斤和1.2公斤，体重分别增加了六倍和八倍一个月的时间里。

;

;这对双胞胎熊猫最近还首次成功尝试翻身。

;

;“借鉴艾宝与韩国第一只熊猫宝宝 Fu 的育儿经验“宝，她很熟练地照顾这对双胞胎大熊猫。”爱宝乐园动物园管理员说道。 “我们正在根据双胞胎大熊猫的健康状况和生长阶段调整喂养频率和配方奶粉量。”

;

;双胞胎大熊猫100天后将被命名。

;

;成长历程您可以在爱宝乐园的 YouTube 频道、爱宝乐园博客和 Zootopia Naver Cafe 上观看这对双胞胎熊猫的动态。他们的相关视频累计观看次数超过3000万，建立了粉丝群。

;

;随着双胞胎大熊猫的不断成长，他们将逐渐过渡到固体食物，他们的视力也将开始发育。预计它们将在四个月左右迈出第一步。

;

;大约六个月大时，双胞胎大熊猫在最初食用母乳和配方奶的混合物后将开始吃竹子。此时，熊猫世界的游客可以期待见到这些可爱的生物。

;

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Former Japanese prime minister Taro Aso arrives in Taiwan to give keynote speech at regional security forumhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3230288/former-japanese-prime-minister-taro-aso-arrives-taiwan-give-key-note-speech-regional-security-forum?utm_source=rss_feed

;日本前首相麻生太郎抵达台湾进行为期三天的访问这次访问肯定会激怒北京。

;

;作为执政党自民党的副主席，这位长期直言不讳的台湾支持者是该党中访问过台湾的最高级别政治人物。自1972年日本与台北断交以来，麻生太郎一行在送行后于周一抵达台北松山机场，其成员包括日本国会议员铃木圭介和中西健二。台湾事实上的驻日大使谢长廷从东京接见。

;

;“[自民党]副总裁麻生太郎的访问不仅代表了台湾与日本之间的牢固关系，也表明双方将台湾外交部表示，但没有详细说明具体是哪些领域。

;

;麻生太郎预计将与台湾总统蔡英文、副总统赖清德、据外务省称，外交部长吴钊燮、前立法院院长王金平和台北市市长蒋万安。

;

;外务省表示，麻生太郎将于周二在一个地区安全论坛上发表主题演讲。周一，麻生太郎和他的代表团在新北的已故台湾总统李登辉的坟墓前向他致敬。< /p>;

;北京将台湾视为其领土，必须将其置于其控制之下，必要时可以使用武力。它警告承认北京而不是台北的国家不要与这个自治岛屿进行官方接触。包括美国在内的大多数国家都不承认台湾是一个独立国家，但反对任何单方面武力改变两岸现状的行为。

;

;全球前七大经济体中，亚洲占据了五席。强大的海军。新加坡排名第24位

;

;麻生太郎的访问预计会激怒北京，北京长期以来一直对他的反北京言论感到不满，包括他在过去两年中宣称台湾的突发事件是日本的突发事件的言论。

;

;麻生太郎在 2021 年 7 月的政党筹款活动中表示，如果台湾遭到入侵，日本需要与美国一起保卫台湾，因为“如果台湾发生重大问题，说这可能与日本面临“生存威胁”的情况并不过分。

;

;他说，这种情况是日本行使其权利所需满足的条件之一集体自卫，或向遭受攻击的盟友提供援助。麻生太郎说：“我们需要认真思考冲绳可能会成为下一个。”

;

;他去年和今年早些时候发表了类似的言论，呼吁大幅加强日本的防御，以应对台湾可能遭受的攻击。他强调，这还可能导致包括冲绳在内的日本领土上的军事冲突。

;

;预计北京将密切关注麻生太郎在台湾的讲话以及与高级官员的会面。

;

; p>;

;麻生太郎访问之际，北京派遣数十架战机和军舰在台湾周围执行任务，加大了对台湾的压力。

;

;周日早上 6 点到周一早上 6 点之间，24 架中国人民解放军战机和 7 架台北国防部周一表示，有军舰在台湾周围活动，其中有 12 艘军舰跨越台湾海峡分隔台湾岛和大陆的中线。

;

;同时，当地新闻媒体报道称，麻生太郎将与台湾会面台湾副总统兼总统竞选领先者赖智，如果他在一月份的竞选中当选，可能会了解他的政治观点和未来政策。

;

;日本和韩国能否在美国峰会上缔结“历史性”安全联盟？

;

;赖智是唯一一位尚未与麻生太郎交谈过的总统候选人。赖智的对手、主要反对党国民党新北市市长侯裕义和反对党台湾人民党党魁、前台北市市长柯文哲最近都在访问东京时会见了自民党副领导人。

;

;麻生太郎四月在东京会见了台湾富士康创始人郭台铭。在访问日本之前，郭台铭曾寻求国民党提名竞选总统，但当该党于 5 月选择侯作为候选人时，他的尝试失败了。

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 20:20:02 +0800 Tech war: Huawei to revive smartphone business on the back of fresh AI-powered operating system even as US sanctions continue to bitehttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3230293/tech-war-huawei-revive-smartphone-business-back-fresh-ai-powered-operating-system-even-us-sanctions?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.07 20:09;
;;

;华为技术有限公司预计将凭借其曾经辉煌的智能手机业务重振雄风尽管这家被列入美国黑名单的公司继续面临 5G 芯片供应的不确定性和充满挑战的宏观经济环境，但鸿蒙操作系统仍进行了最新升级。

;

;“华为的旗舰智能手机正在卷土重来，”华为首席执行官余承东说道。该公司消费者业务集团及其智能汽车解决方案业务部门的高管上周五在广东省东莞市举行的年度开发者大会上表示，HarmonyOS 4 是在该大会上发布的。

;

;余的乐观评价根据研究公司 IDC 的数据，私人控股的华为在第二季度重新成为中国大陆排名前五的智能手机供应商。华为在 2020 年第二季度超越三星电子，成为全球最大的智能手机供应商，但由于美国制裁收紧，切断了其先进移动芯片的供应，该业务随后陷入困境。

;

;在其开发商处发布会上，华为表示，HarmonyOS 4 已与公司自有的生成式人工智能模型盘古集成，提供类似 ChatGPT 的服务，包括自动消息传递和创建图像。

;

;HarmonyOS 4 预计还将增强对其他产品的支持智能电动汽车等设备是华为近年来瞄准的主要领域。余承东在大会上表示，鸿蒙操作系统现已连接超过 7 亿台设备，其生态系统拥有超过 220 万开发者。

;

;这一最新进展反映了华为为加强其全球业务所付出的努力，因为美国的贸易制裁继续产生影响，在今年早些时候有报道称拜登政府希望切断该公司与所有美国供应商的联系后，该公司正在权衡如何应对美中脱钩。

;

;最新消息Counterpoint Research 高级分析师 Ivan Lam 周一表示，HarmonyOS 的迭代对于华为的智能手机战略“至关重要”，华为的智能手机战略旨在改善软件方面的体验，以弥补硬件方面的某些劣势。

;< p>;“HarmonyOS 的目标一直是……通过在配备不太先进芯片的华为设备上创造更流畅的体验来做出巨大贡献，”Lam 说。

;

;HarmonyOS 首次亮相是作为替代操作系统2019 年 8 月，即华为被列入华盛顿实体名单三个月后。根据这份贸易黑名单，华为被禁止从美国供应商购买软件、芯片和其他技术，包括从谷歌购买Android平台。

;

;过去一年，华为成功保持了9至9%的相对稳定份额。据 Counterpoint 的 Lam 称，该公司在全球最大智能手机市场中国的份额为 12%。

;

;第二季度，该公司在中国大陆的智能手机销量份额同比增长 58%，占 11.3% Counterpoint 数据显示，在产品发布步伐恢复的情况下，华为在国内市场的份额将有所提高。

;

;“如果华为能够保持稳定的市场份额，那么其增长势头就可以持续下去，尽管整体来看，华为的增长势头仍然强劲。”

;

;中国智能手机市场季度跌幅收窄，华为重回前五

;

;上半年华为在中国智能手机出货量总计 1,430 万部IDC 亚太区高级研究经理 Will Wong 表示，预计到 2023 年，与去年同期相比将增长近 40%，这得益于该行业高端市场的恢复力。

;

;“其中一个“产品发布速度加快的关键原因是华为在经历了多年美国制裁的负面影响后成功优化了供应链。”Wong 表示。

;

;尽管如此，华为仍未能推出新产品自 2020 年底以来，华为一直在推出 5G 智能手机，并且在过去几年中错过了对其高端智能手机型号的几次更新。

;

;华为在中断一年多后于 4 月份恢复了旗舰 P 系列智能手机的发布。其最新的 Mate 系列手机在跳过 2021 年更新后于去年 9 月发布。但这两款机型仅支持 4G 连接。

;

;受到美国制裁的华为通过地方政府协议加强了对国内市场的关注

;

; h3>;

;根据路透社上个月的一份报告，该公司预计将在今年年底恢复 5G 智能手机的发布，因为它从当地供应商那里获得了新的芯片供应，该报告援引了多家研究公司的话说消息来源。

;

;尽管华为已经解决了某些供应链问题并采用了国产替代品，但 Counterpoint 的 Lam 表示，采购最新相机和 5G 芯片仍存在挥之不去的不确定性。

;

;“在最好的情况下如果华为采购5G芯片并用在旗舰机型上，会对华为带来小幅提振，但不足以带动其销量重回市场前三。” “即使解决了5G芯片问题，生产规模可能仍会受到限制。”

;朝鲜黑客精英组织秘密破坏了俄罗斯一家主要导弹开发商的计算机网络根据路透社审查的技术证据和安全研究人员的分析，去年至少有五个月的时间。

;

;路透社发现与朝鲜政府有秘密联系的网络间谍团队（安全研究人员称之为 ScarCruft 和 Lazarus）在位于莫斯科郊区鲁托夫小镇的火箭设计局 NPO Mashinostroyeniya 的系统中安装了隐秘的数字后门。

;

;路透社无法确定入侵期间是否窃取了任何数据或获取了哪些信息可能已被查看。在数字入侵后的几个月里，平壤宣布了其被禁止的弹道导弹计划的几项进展，但尚不清楚这是否与此次入侵有关。

;

;专家表示，这一事件表明这个孤立的国家将如何甚至瞄准其盟友，例如俄罗斯，以获取关键技术。

;

;NPO Mashinostroyeniya 没有回应路透社的置评请求。俄罗斯驻华盛顿大使馆没有回复通过电子邮件发送的置评请求。朝鲜驻纽约联合国代表团没有回应置评请求。

;

;俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古上个月访问平壤庆祝朝鲜成立 70 周年后不久，就传出了有关黑客攻击的消息。朝鲜战争，这是自 1991 年苏联解体以来俄罗斯国防部长首次访问朝鲜。

;

;目标公司（通常称为 NPO Mash）是导弹专家表示，高超音速导弹、卫星技术和新一代弹道武器——自朝鲜开始执行制造能够打击美国本土的洲际弹道导弹（ICBM）的任务以来，这三个领域一直是朝鲜非常感兴趣的领域。

;

;根据技术数据，入侵大致开始于 2021 年底，一直持续到 2022 年 5 月，根据路透社查阅的该公司内部通信，IT 工程师检测到了黑客的活动。

;

;NPO马什在冷战期间作为俄罗斯太空计划的主要卫星制造商和巡航导弹供应商而声名鹊起。

;

;

;

;黑客深入公司的 IT 环境，为他们提供了最初发现该漏洞的美国网络安全公司 SentinelOne 的安全研究员 Tom Hegel 表示，该漏洞具有读取电子邮件流量、在网络之间跳转和提取数据的能力。 Hegel 表示：“传统上，这些秘密网络行动一直隐藏在公众监督之外，或者根本不会被此类受害者发现。”

;

;Hegel 的 SentinelOne 安全分析师团队在发现 NPO Mash IT 工作人员意外入侵后得知了此次黑客攻击。在试图通过将证据上传到全球网络安全研究人员使用的私人门户网站来调查朝鲜袭击事件时，泄露了公司的内部通信。

;

;当路透社联系该 IT 人员时，该 IT 人员拒绝发表评论。

;< p>;这一失误为路透社和 SentinelOne 提供了一家对俄罗斯国家至关重要的公司的独特快照，该公司在入侵克里米亚后受到奥巴马政府的制裁。

;

;两位独立计算机安全专家 Nicholas Weaver和马特·泰特（Matt Tait）审查了暴露的电子邮件内容并确认了其真实性。分析师通过根据 NPO Mash 控制的一组密钥检查电子邮件的加密签名来验证连接。

;

;“我对数据的真实性非常有信心，”Weaver 告诉路透社。 “信息的泄露方式绝对是一次搞笑的搞砸”。

;

;SentinelOne 表示，他们确信朝鲜是这次黑客攻击的幕后黑手，因为网络间谍重复利用了之前已知的恶意软件和恶意基础设施来执行其他活动入侵。

;

;世界上最强大的 7 个海军中有 5 个在亚洲。新加坡排名第 24 位

;

;2019 年，俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京称赞 NPO Mash 的“锆石”高超音速导弹是“有前途的新产品”，其飞行速度约为音速的九倍。

;

;研究朝鲜导弹计划外国援助的欧洲导弹专家马库斯·席勒 (Markus Schiller) 表示，朝鲜黑客可能已经获得了有关锆石的信息，但这并不意味着他们会立即拥有相同的能力。

;

;“那是电影里的东西，”他说。 “获得计划对你建造这些东西没有多大帮助，它比一些图纸要重要得多。”

;

;但是，考虑到 NPO Mash 作为俄罗斯顶级导弹设计师和生产商的地位，该公司Schiller 补充道，这将是一个有价值的目标。

;

;“他们有很多值得学习的地方，”他说。

;

;另一个令人感兴趣的领域可能是 NPO Mash 使用的制造工艺。周围的燃料，专家说。上个月，朝鲜试射了 Hwasong-18，这是其第一款使用固体推进剂的洲际弹道导弹。

;

;这种加油方法可以在战争期间更快地部署导弹，因为它不需要加油发射台，使导弹在发射前更难跟踪和摧毁。

;

;NPO Mash 生产一种名为 SS-19 的洲际弹道导弹，该弹道导弹在工厂加注燃料并密封关闭，这一过程称为“放大” ”这会产生类似的战略结果。

;

;“这很难做到，因为火箭推进剂，尤其是氧化剂，具有很强的腐蚀性，”詹姆斯·马丁防扩散研究中心的导弹研究员杰弗里·刘易斯说。< /p>;

;“朝鲜宣布将在 2021 年底做同样的事情。如果 NPO Mash 有一件对他们有用的事情，那将是我的首要任务，”他补充道。

;

;朝鲜称美国的台湾武器援助将地区推向“战争的燃点”

;

;与此同时，在朝鲜境内不寻常地看到一架俄罗斯军用飞机，引发了人们对金正恩正在向弗拉基米尔·普京出售武器的担忧随着受制裁国家之间关系的加强。

;

;FlightRadar24 的跟踪数据显示，俄罗斯空军伊留申 IL-62M 于 7 月 31 日从莫斯科飞往平壤，并于 8 月 2 日返回。

;

;卫星imagery showed the aircraft at Pyongyang's international airport for about 36 hours, according to NK News, a Seoul-based provider of news on North Korea that also tracks flight activity in the isolated country.

;

;The flight was the first by this type of Russian military VIP plane to North Korea since mid-2019, when Russian Deputy Defence Minister Alexander Fomin travelled to Pyongyang, NK News said.

;

;Pyongyang closed its borders in early 2020 due to the pandemic, choking its economy.

;

;Neither Russia nor North Korea have reported on the plane, and it is unclear who was aboard. Russia's Defence Ministry did not respond to a request for comment.

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 19:50:02 +0800 Indonesia still keen to court Elon Musk, ‘not worried’ by Tesla’s Malaysia basehttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/economics/article/3230284/indonesia-still-keen-court-elon-musk-not-worried-teslas-malaysia-base?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;As Indonesia continues its years-long effort to court investments from billionaire Elon Musk, observers have said the country's giant nickel reserves may not be as large a draw as hoped, while its fossil fuel reliance suggests Jakarta is “not entirely serious” about its renewable energy push.

;

;Luhut Pandjaitan, Indonesia's coordinating minister of maritime affairs and investment, said last month that he planned to speak with the world's richest man during a visit to California on August 2, in an umpteenth attempt to strike a deal as the country seeks to become a regional electric-vehicle manufacturing hub.

;

;While Jakarta did not confirm if Luhut eventually met Musk, Health Minister Budi Sadikin did score a meeting on August 4 with the entrepreneur to discuss cooperation with his satellite network, Starlink, to provide low-cost internet access to remote health centres in the archipelago. “With internet access, health service consultations can be done online,” Budi said on Sunday.

;

;Jakarta's dogged charm offensive comes even as it has been left humbled by the businessman's decision to house Tesla's Southeast Asian headquarters in neighbouring Malaysia, where it launched operations on July 20 with the release of its Model Y and Model 3 cars, priced from 199,000 ringgit (US$43,600) to 288,000 ringgit.

;

;Many Indonesian publications took a dim view of the development, saying Jakarta had been “snubbed”, while The Jakarta Post said Indonesia's window to become a major EV manufacturer was closing.

;

;“Jetting across the world to convince would-be investors is a noble effort, but something may be lacking in Indonesia's offer. We have the biggest economy in Southeast Asia, a growing consumer market, EV purchasing incentives and the world's largest nickel reserves,” the newspaper said in an editorial on August 3. “Should global players not be scrambling to invest here?”

;

;Malaysia's already won over Tesla and Amazon. Will Google, Microsoft be next?

;

;Officials from Luhut's ministry have spent the past week reassuring the public that Tesla's new regional headquarters in Selangor was not a sign that Indonesia was being overlooked by Musk.

;

;“Tesla's investment in Malaysia is not [in the form of] an EV factory, but for sales and distribution, so we're not too worried about that,” Septian Hario Seto, deputy for investment and mining coordination at the ministry, said on July 25. “What we are targeting are EV factories. For Malaysia, it only invests in distribution and charging networks.”

;

;Indonesian officials have also made a few unsubstantiated claims to prove their efforts were not fruitless. Last August, Luhut claimed Tesla had agreed to purchase US$5 billion worth of Indonesian nickel produced by China's Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt and CNGR Advanced Material. Tesla has never commented on this claim.

;

;In February, Widodo said in an interview with Reuters that he was “confident” Tesla would invest, as the country had the world's biggest nickel reserves at 21 million metric tonnes. Nickel is a key material in EV batteries.

;

;“I said to [Musk] that if you invest in Indonesia, I will give concessions in nickel [mining],” Widodo had said. Tesla has not made any decisions to date.

;

;Andry Satrio Nugroho, a researcher of industry, trade and investment at the Institute for Development of Economics and Finance in Jakarta, said nickel was not likely to be an attraction for Tesla.

;

;“Tesla doesn't use nickel-based batteries any more, so it will be difficult for Indonesia to get Tesla to set up an EV battery facility here,” he said. “One of the things that made Musk switch to [lithium iron phosphate] batteries was Indonesia's ban of nickel ore export, which made nickel prices go up.”

;

;LFP batteries do not contain nickel or cobalt, and are easier and cheaper to make, although they pack less energy density than nickel-based batteries.

;

;'We shouldn't be gutless': Indonesia doubles down on bauxite ore export ban

;

;Nugroho said, however, that competition with Malaysia was not a zero-sum game. There was still room for Musk's investments in Indonesia, namely for his aerospace company SpaceX and its subsidiary Starlink, which provides high-speed satellite internet to remote areas, he said.

;

;“Indonesia already uses SpaceX services to launch its satellites. Jokowi also eventually needs to say that the country needs Starlink for the remote regions; it will be a win-win solution for Indonesia and Starlink,” he said, referring to Widodo's popular nickname.

;

;

;

;Apart from selling cars, Tesla is establishing a head office, service hub and experience centre in Malaysia's Selangor, and will invest “significantly” in a network of fast-charging and regular-charging stations across the country.

;

;Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said Musk was also interested in rolling out his Starlink satellite service across the country.

;

;He said “political stability” had brought Tesla to the nation of 33.9 million people. “When the unity government came about, there is political stability … When the political climate is stable, people are sure to come,” he said during a speech on July 28.

;

;Will Malaysia put energy exports to Singapore before its green economy plans?

;

;According to Anwar, it was Musk who had contacted him for a meeting, after a previous request made by a former minister failed.

;

;“Elon Musk is the richest person in the world. Elon Musk is richer than countries. It is quite difficult to bring him in. But once we became stable, I didn't ask to talk to him; he asked to talk to me,” he said.

;

;But analysts note that political stability is not the sole driver for Tesla's investments in the region. Before Malaysia's election last November, the country had three prime ministers in three years, and a unity government consisting of Anwar's party and former foes was forged to calm divisions in the country. In comparison, Widodo has governed Indonesia since 2014, with his coalition making up more than 81 per cent of seats in parliament.

;

;Indonesia, however, fares poorly in environmental social governance (ESG) aspects, a set of standards used by a company to screen potential investments, Nugroho of Indef said.

;

;“There are still many issues that Indonesia has not complied with enough, especially the ESG aspects of its nickel mining sector. From there, maybe Tesla withdrew its intention to build [a manufacturing facility] here,” Nugroho said.

;

;There have been reports in recent years detailing the harsh conditions faced by workers in Indonesia's nickel-mining hub of Sulawesi, where many Chinese firms have set up shop, as well as the environmental damage caused by the operations of smelters, which are reliant on fossil fuels.

;

;Daymas Arangga, executive director at Jakarta-based Energy Watch, said Jakarta was “not entirely focused and serious” in transitioning to renewable energy, as fossil fuels still accounted for 60 per cent of Indonesia's energy supply. The lack of green energy may have reduced investor appetite, especially EV producers, to set up shop domestically, he said.

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 19:50:02 +0800 Hong Kong scientists have lift-off for research project after expert wins bid for use of moon rocks and dust to study lunar volcanic activityhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3230268/hong-kong-scientists-have-lift-research-project-after-expert-wins-bid-use-moon-rocks-and-dust-study?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;Rocks and dust from the moon have touched down in Hong Kong and researchers said the rare samples would help pave the way for future developments in lunar research in the city.

;

;Dr Qian Yuqi, a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Hong Kong (HKU), on Monday unveiled the 822.6 milligrams of lunar material, which included some of the youngest moon rocks ever found.

;

;He picked up the precious samples in person from the China National Space Administration's Lunar Exploration and Space Engineering Centre in Beijing late last month.

;

;“This is the first time Hong Kong, as the main applicant, has obtained lunar samples. We hope to use geological methods to study the lunar magma's process, from the beginning of the eruption in the moon's core to travelling up the vent, to know more about its temperature and speed of eruption,” Qian said.

;

;He applied to borrow the samples for a year. Qian submitted a proposal and orally defended it in front of a panel of Chinese space agency experts in April against strong competition.

;

;Advanced HKU laboratory equipment can analyse elements in the sample, which will provide information about the lunar environment and formation of soil and give insights into the early history of the moon and Earth.

;

;“In the last 20 years, China has become one of the world leaders in space exploration, especially the moon and Mars,” HKU associate professor Dr Joseph Michalski said.

;

;“We're very excited about future plans along those lines and for other planetary science missions.

;

;“Planetary science is not just about studying things away from Earth, but it teaches us about our own planet as well.

;

;“By studying the ancient crust of the moon and Mars, we learn fundamental things about how planets formed, fundamental processes about how volcanoes worked and how crust evolved.”

;

;The samples were collected in 2020 by China's Chang'e-5 lunar mission, and include 800mg of lunar dust and 22.6mg of lunar rock.

;

;Preliminary research of the basalt rock samples by mainland Chinese scientists showed they were formed from magma from a volcanic eruption about 2 billion years ago, around a billion years later than the rocks collected on moon missions by the US and former Soviet Union.

;

;Qian, who has been studying a region of the moon with one of the youngest areas of mare basalts, said the samples could provide information to show that lunar volcanoes might be more active than at first thought.

;

;Hong Kong university builds case for using antidiabetic drug for anti-ageing

;

;He and his team explained they hoped to use the samples to recreate and analyse the basalt eruption process, which formed the moon's surface.

;

;Qian said the team wanted to study other samples in the future, including rocks collected from the far side of the moon in next year's Chang'e-6 mission, or from the Chinese mission to Mars scheduled for the next decade.

;

;The 28-year-old, who completed his first degree and doctorate at the China University of Geosciences in Wuhan between 2013 and 2022, joined HKU in March because he felt Hong Kong lacked expertise in moon studies.

;

;Scientists work to replicate lunar soil for China's moon building project

;

;“HKU has a very strong earth sciences faculty with a lot of advanced equipment, but no one was specialising in lunar science,” Qian said.

;

;;

;Japan will reportedly start to release treated radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the Pacific Ocean as soon as the end of August, a move that has barely elicited a ripple among the Japanese public.

;

;Critics of the plan to discharge around 1.25 million tons of water from the plant, where three reactors suffered meltdowns after the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami, say the public has been swayed by an effective campaign by the Japanese government – assisted by the domestic media – to convince the nation that it is safe to release the water.

;

;That effort to win over waverers at home has been abetted by what one analyst described as “nationalist victimisation”, with the Japanese government accusing China of ignoring what it insists is sound science behind the plan, of attacking the findings of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and being guilty of far more egregious releases from its own nuclear plants.

;

;Conservative media have for some weeks been insisting that Beijing's opposition to the release is purely for its political and geopolitical aims, a message that appears to be resonating with the public as bilateral tensions worsen over issues ranging from Taiwan to access to advanced technology and rare earth minerals.

;

;More liberal media have recently joined in the accusations that China's protests are motivated by political opportunism.

;

;The Asahi newspaper reported on Monday that Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is likely to give Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco), the operator of the plant, final approval to start discharging the water after he returns from a three-way summit with US President Joe Biden and South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol at the US leader's retreat at Camp David, outside Washington DC, on August 18.

;

;“I really thought the release was going to be postponed, so this is very disappointing,” said Aileen Mioko-Smith, a campaigner with Kyoto-based Green Action Japan.

;

;“A lot of issues connected with the release – primarily a lot of the questions raised by governments on islands in the Pacific that are likely to be most affected by the release – have simply not been answered,” she said.

;

;“The Japanese government keeps repeating that the IAEA has declared that everything is fine and that it is completely safe to release the water. That is being repeated by the media and people are finally accepting it.

;

;“Ordinary people do not have the scientific knowledge to contradict everything they are being told. My sense is that the public really don't think this is the best course of action, but they also do not know how they can express their concerns and resist,” Mioko-Smith said.

;

;“Now the emphasis is also shifting to how China is ignoring the scientists and is being irrational for its own ends,” she added.

;

;'I would be willing': South Korean PM offers to drink treated Fukushima water

;

;A July 15 report in the Sankei paper accused Beijing of fomenting opposition in South Korea to Japan's plans for the water, out of anger at Seoul, Tokyo and Washington forging closer diplomatic and security ties, adding that China's government was using a “velvet paw” to “tighten its grip” on South Korea.

;

;Similarly, the Yomiuri Shimbun on Sunday quoted Akira Amari, secretary general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, as saying, “China makes claims that are not scientific” and that Beijing “uses unfounded rumours as a diplomatic tool”.

;

;Even left-leaning media outlets have started repeating that line in recent weeks, with an editorial in the Asahi newspaper on July 21 stating, “China is using Japan's plan to release treated radioactive water into the Pacific Ocean for political purposes amid its strained relationship with Japan”.

;

;The editorial criticised Beijing's decision to step up radiation tests on imported Japanese seafood imports, adding: “It is hard not to suspect that the Chinese government is using the issue of treated water as a way to put pressure on Japan and promote internationally the view that it is Japan that is disrupting the international order.”

;

;Jeff Kingston, director of Asian Studies at the Tokyo campus of Temple University, said Japan and Tepco had been forced into “whataboutism” – accusing China of releasing more radioactive water from its nuclear plants than Japan – because earlier efforts to reassure the domestic public and foreign governments failed.

;

;“Tepco has not covered itself in glory by failing to really consult local stakeholders, local fishermen, nearby residents and civil society at large,” he said. “And by failing to do that due diligence, they have sown mistrust.”

;

;With the reputation of the nation's nuclear industry tarnished, Japan is “spattering its critics to deflect more criticism”, Kingston said, while the domestic “media marches in unison”.

;

;The Japanese public's position on the issue has been shifted by claims that the nation is the target of unfair criticism from its rivals, he added.

;

;“Playing the nationalist victimisation card has worked in the past for Japan, and it appears to be working again now,” he said. “I think most of those who were opposed to the release will remain opposed, but there were a lot of people sitting on the fence, and I think they will have been swayed by this new argument.”
